content: totally biased by susan ashcroft there are quite a few notes to guide you but this is a quick and easy knit - great for last-minute presents or spoiling yourself knitting on the bias isn t much trickier than ordinary knitting and it produces an interesting effect - perfect for showcasing long-striping or hand-painted yarns lacy version a cowl is the easiest way to knit on the you can use almost any yarn and bias because all the row are worked in corresponding needle size the same way to produce a parallelogram and then you just join the two ends use ravelry s yarn ideas tab on the pattern page check the project pages for you will probably be able to make one in examples or just be inspired by your just a couple of hours yarn some suggested yarns and stitch counts are dk or aran - 4 5mm or larger us7 - 36 to 40 stitches super bulky - 6mm or larger us 10 - minimum 26 stitches you ll need about 100m of yarn for finer yarn i used about 200m and noro kureyon 4-row repeat made a double loop using 30 stitches to print just the instructions - you ll only need to print pg 4 or 5 © susan ashcroft 2011 - for personal non-commercial use only page 1 notes and tips gauge for this pattern gauge and size aren t particularly critical you can try it on and decide on the length as you go but you won t be able to change the height i make mine wide and then they can be folded in half or just under at the top edge if you want to make a swatch to get a specific height the best thing would be to knit it on the bias good practice for the technique and then position it as shown here and measure on the vertical axis i e the height if you want to use a finished non-bias stockinette project or swatch to check gauge just turn it to the same position and measure handpainted yarn 6-row repeat provisional cast on the best way is usually the crochet method but it may be difficult to unpick at the increase/decrease so i recommend my lazy non-crochet method use cable cast on with a contrast yarn and then just cut away the waste yarn once you have inserted the needle into the stitches you need live here s a link for provisional cast on http //www knittinghelp com/video/play/invisible- provisional-cast-on kitchener stitch grafting it s true it s a bit fiddly but i think it s worth it so that you have a seamless cowl you can wear on either side and which you can turn to have the colours you like at the front here s a link to a good video http //www knittinghelp com/video/play/kitchener-stitch if you really can t face it just use regular cast on and bind off and then join as neatly as
